articles.content: NASA has shared a new picture of Jupiter's Europa moon, which is the smallest of the gas giant's four Galilean moons and also the sixth largest moon in our solar system. The picture was taken by NASA's Juno spacecraft on September 29, 2022. It revealed the "complex, ice-covered surface" of Europa as captured by Juno during its flyby.
articles.title: NASA releases new pic of Jupiter's ice-covered moon Europa captured by Juno
articles.subtitle: 'Juno exploring full Jovian system'

articles.content: Serbian scientists named a new species of beetle after ex-world number one men's tennis player Novak Djokovic. The insect, which belongs to Duvalius genus of ground beetles present in Europe and was discovered several years ago in underground pit in Serbia, has been named 'Duvalius djokovici'. "We feel urged to pay Djokovic back in...way we can," a researcher said.
articles.title: New species of beetle named after Novak Djokovic
articles.subtitle: 'He is the man who did much for this country'

articles.content: The Draconid meteor shower is all set to light up the skies between 9 to 10 October. According to NASA, these meteors are generally faint owing to their relatively slow movement as they enter Earth's atmosphere at just 40,000 mph. Hence, researchers believe, this time, the meteor might appear even fainter due to the full moon rising on October 9.
articles.title: Draconid meteor shower set to light up skies on October 9 &10
articles.subtitle: Draconid meteor may be lost in the moonlight

articles.content: As per researchers, a new supercontinent will be created as the Pacific ocean is slowly closing up. It's shrinking by around one inch a year, due to which the tectonic plates on which the Americas rest are getting pushed westwards, they said. After 200-300 million years, the landmasses of Americas and Asia might collide to create a new supercontinent, Amasia.
articles.title: New supercontinent 'Amasia' will be created as Pacific ocean shrinks: Study
articles.subtitle: Australia might play a vital role in this event

articles.content: NASA shared satellite images showing aerial view of US' Florida before and after the approach of "extremely dangerous" Hurricane Ian. "Turquoise colour is likely sediment that Ian lifted from...seafloor," said NASA. Prior to the storm, there was already some colour, but much of that is due to light reflecting off sea grass beds, seafloor and coral reefs, it added.
articles.title: Pics show aerial view of US' Florida before and after Hurricane Ian's approach
articles.subtitle: It brought sustained winds of about 240 kmph

articles.content: Scientists have confirmed that orcas hunt great white sharks, after drone and helicopter footage showed first evidence of a pod of orcas killing a great white near Mossel Bay in South Africa. The footage shows five killer whales chasing sharks in an hour-long pursuit, before killing one of them. Researchers believe that three other sharks may also have been killed.
articles.title: Orcas caught chasing, killing great white shark on video for the first time
articles.subtitle: 'This hasn't been witnessed in detail before'

articles.content: Astronomers have discovered a pair of stars with an extremely short orbit that appear to circle each other every 51 minutes. The system could be a "cataclysmic variable," in which a sun-like star orbits tightly around a white dwarf, a hot, dense core of a burned-out star. In next 70 million years, their orbital period would reduce to 18 minutes.
articles.title: 'Cataclysmic' pair of stars that orbit each other in less than an hour discovered
articles.subtitle: The stars are going to speed up: Study

articles.content: Scientists have said that reflections on the surface of Mars under its south pole could be caused by layers of ice and carbon dioxide and not by water. "On Earth, reflections that are bright are often an indication of liquid water, even buried lakes...But on Mars...it should be too cold for similar lakes to form," a researcher said.
articles.title: Reflections from Mars not caused due to water: Scientists
articles.subtitle: Discovery of water on Mars is vital for humans

articles.content: A fossil of a cat-sized reptile that was closely related to an extinct group of flying reptiles known as pterosaurs has been unearthed in Scotland. Named Scleromochlus taylori, the reptile lived on Earth about 240 to 210 million years ago. Scleromochlus had a large head, a long tail, a short neck, and a slender body, and stood on spindly legs.
articles.title: Fossil of cat-sized reptile, an early relative of flying reptile, found in Scotland
articles.subtitle: It was no more than 20 cm long

articles.content: Air pollution particles have been found in developing lungs and brains of unborn babies for the first time, a study by University of Aberdeen and Hasselt University in Belgium stated. Thousands of black carbon particles were found in each cubic millimetre of tissue, which were breathed in by mother during pregnancy and then passed through bloodstream and placenta to foetus.
articles.title: Toxic air pollution particles found in lungs, brains of unborn babies for the first time
articles.subtitle: 'Very worrying,' researchers said about findings
